title: The Frogs and the Ox
narration: Once upon a time, an Ox came down to a reedy pool to drink. As he splashed heavily into the water, he crushed a young Frog into the mud. The old Frog soon noticed the little one was missing and asked his brothers and sisters what had become of him. 'A great big monster,' said one of them, 'stepped on little brother with one of his huge feet!' 'Big, was he!' said the old Frog, puffing herself up. 'Was he as big as this?' 'Oh, much bigger!' they cried. The Frog puffed up still more. 'He could not have been bigger than this,' she insisted. But the little Frogs all declared the monster was much, much bigger. The old Frog kept puffing herself out more and more until, at last, she burst.
lesson: Do not attempt the impossible.

title: Belling the Cat
narration: Once, the Mice called a meeting to free themselves from their enemy, the Cat. 'We must find a way of knowing when she is coming, so we may have time to run away,' they said, living in constant fear of her claws. Many plans were discussed, but none seemed good enough. At last, a young Mouse stood up. 'I have a plan that is very simple, and it will surely succeed. All we need to do is hang a bell around the Cat’s neck. When we hear the bell, we will know immediately that our enemy is near.' All the Mice were surprised they had never thought of such a clever idea. But in the midst of their rejoicing, an old Mouse spoke: 'Yes, the plan is very good. But let me ask one question: Who will bell the Cat?'
lesson: It is one thing to say something should be done, but quite another to do it.

title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
narration: A Town Mouse once visited her cousin in the countryside. For lunch, the Country Mouse served wheat stalks, roots, and acorns, with cold water to drink. The Town Mouse nibbled sparingly, making it very plain that she ate such simple food only to be polite. That night, the Country Mouse dreamed of the luxuries her cousin described. The next morning, when invited to visit the city, she gladly agreed. In the Town Mouse’s home, a grand feast awaited them—cakes, pastries, jellies, and cheeses. The Country Mouse was about to nibble when suddenly a Cat meowed, and the Mice scurried to hide. When they returned, servants and a Dog entered, frightening her even more. Shaking, the Country Mouse packed her bag. 'You may have luxuries and dainties that I have not,' she said, 'but I prefer my plain food and simple life with peace and safety.'
lesson: Poverty with security is better than plenty with fear.

title: The Fox and the Grapes
narration: One hot day, a Fox spotted a bunch of ripe grapes hanging from a vine. They looked ready to burst with juice, and his mouth watered. The grapes hung high, and the Fox leapt for them again and again, but he always fell short. At last, he sat down in disgust. 'What a fool I am,' he said. 'Here I am wearing myself out for a bunch of sour grapes that are not worth my trouble.'
lesson: It is easy to despise what you cannot have.

title: The Wolf and the Kid
narration: A young Kid, who had strayed from the flock, stood on the roof of a house as the Wolf passed by. 'You may be a master of strength,' called the Kid, 'but up here, I am master of wit.' The Wolf snarled, 'It is not you mocking me, but the roof that gives you safety.'
lesson: Do not despise the weak when they are safe.

title: The Lion and the Mouse
narration: One day, a tiny Mouse ran across a sleeping Lion. The great beast woke and caught her. Terrified, the Mouse begged, 'Please let me go! Someday I may repay you.' The Lion laughed at such an idea but released her. Later, the Lion was trapped in a hunter’s net. The little Mouse heard his roars and ran to help. With sharp teeth, she gnawed through the ropes until the Lion was free. 'You laughed when I promised to repay you,' said the Mouse. 'Now you see that even a small friend can be of great help.'
lesson: Even the smallest creature can be of great use.

title: The Crow and the Pitcher
narration: On a hot day, a thirsty Crow found a pitcher with only a little water at the bottom. He tried and tried to reach it but could not. Then the clever bird picked up pebbles and dropped them one by one into the pitcher. Slowly, the water rose high enough for him to drink.
lesson: Little by little, effort succeeds.

title: The Ant and the Dove
narration: A thirsty Ant went to drink from a stream but slipped and fell. A Dove perched on a branch nearby saw her struggling. Quickly, the Dove dropped a leaf, and the Ant climbed to safety. Soon after, a hunter crept up to catch the Dove. The Ant bit him on the foot, and in pain, he missed his shot. The Dove flew away unharmed.
lesson: A kindness is never wasted.

title: The Dog and His Reflection
narration: A Dog once stole a piece of meat and ran off with it. Crossing a bridge, he looked into the water and saw his reflection. Thinking it was another Dog with a bigger piece, he snapped at it. His own meat fell into the river and was lost.
lesson: Beware of greed—it may cost you what you already have.

title: The Shepherd Boy and the Wolf
narration: A Shepherd Boy, bored while tending sheep, thought of a trick. He cried out, 'Wolf! Wolf!' and the villagers rushed to help, only to find it was a joke. The boy laughed, and the trick worked a second time. But when a real Wolf came and attacked the flock, the boy cried out again. This time, no one came, for they thought he was lying. The Wolf scattered the sheep, and the boy wept.
lesson: Liars are not believed, even when they tell the truth.

title: The Gnat and the Bull
narration: One summer day, a Bull was quietly grazing when a tiny Gnat settled on one of his horns. After a while, the Gnat prepared to fly away. “Do forgive me,” he buzzed politely, “for resting so long upon your horn. I fear I may have been in your way.” The Bull raised his head and replied, “Oh, not at all. I did not even notice you were there.”
lesson: We are often not as important as we think.

title: The Plane Tree
narration: Two weary travelers rested under the broad shade of a Plane Tree. Looking up, one said, “What a useless tree this is! No fruit, no nuts, nothing but leaves.” The tree rustled its branches in anger. “Ungrateful men!” it said. “You lie here in my cool shade and call me useless. What would you do without me?”
lesson: Our most useful blessings are often the least appreciated.

title: The Farmer and the Stork
narration: A Farmer set a net in his field to catch the cranes that came to steal his grain. Among those caught was a Stork. “Please let me go,” pleaded the Stork. “I am no crane! I am a good bird who honors my father and mother. I do not steal.” But the Farmer shook his head. “You may be innocent yourself, but I caught you among thieves. You must share their fate.”
lesson: You are judged by the company you keep.

title: The Sheep and the Pig
narration: A Shepherd caught a Pig and carried it off, squealing loudly. The Sheep, who heard, were much disturbed. “Listen to him,” they said, “he makes such a fuss when we are caught and dragged off, yet we say nothing at all.” The Pig squealed, “You Sheep may be taken only for your wool. But I am taken for my life!”
lesson: It is easy to be brave when nothing is at stake.

title: The Fisherman and the Little Fish
narration: A poor Fisherman once caught a tiny Fish. “Please, good sir,” begged the Fish, “throw me back. I am too small to be worth eating. If you let me grow, someday I shall be big enough to make you a fine meal.” But the Fisherman shook his head. “Little fool! I would be a great fool indeed to throw you back. I may not catch you again, and a little fish is better than none.”
lesson: A small gain is better than none at all.

title: The Wolf and the Crane
narration: A Wolf once got a bone stuck in his throat and howled in pain. He begged every animal to help, promising a great reward. At last, a Crane agreed. She thrust her long beak down his throat and drew out the bone. When she asked for her reward, the Wolf laughed. “Be content! You put your head into a Wolf’s mouth and took it out again safely. That is reward enough!”
lesson: Expect no reward for serving the wicked.

title: The Crows and the Pitcher
narration: A flock of Crows were dying of thirst. They found a pitcher with only a little water inside. One clever Crow said, “We can solve this together.” They each picked pebbles and dropped them into the pitcher. Slowly, the water rose, and at last, all the Crows were able to drink.
lesson: Unity and effort bring success.

title: The Goose and the Golden Eggs
narration: A Farmer had a Goose that laid a golden egg every day. At first, he was delighted and grew rich. But soon, greed overtook him. “If the Goose lays golden eggs, she must be filled with gold inside,” he thought. So he killed her, only to find she was like any other goose. His treasure was gone forever.
lesson: Greed often loses all.

title: The Farmer and His Sons
narration: A dying Farmer called his sons and said, “There is treasure hidden in our vineyard. Dig for it after I am gone.” After his death, the sons dug eagerly. They turned up every inch of the vineyard but found no gold. Yet the vines, so well worked, yielded a rich harvest.
lesson: Hard work itself is a treasure.

title: The Wolf and the Lamb
narration: One day, a Lamb strayed from the flock and came to a stream where a Wolf was drinking. “How dare you muddy my water!” snarled the Wolf. “I am downstream,” replied the Lamb meekly. “The water flows to me, not to you.” “You insult me last year!” roared the Wolf. “I was not even born then,” said the Lamb. “No matter,” growled the Wolf. And he seized the Lamb and devoured him.
lesson: The tyrant always finds an excuse for his tyranny.

title: The Peacock and the Crane
narration: Once upon a time, a Peacock spread his bright, shimmering tail and boasted to a Crane. “Look at my dazzling feathers! No bird is as splendid as I.” The Crane replied calmly, “Your feathers are fair indeed, but I can rise up and soar into the heavens, while you only strut upon the ground.”
lesson: Fine feathers don’t make fine birds.

title: The Farmer and the Snake
narration: On a frosty winter morning, a Farmer found a half-frozen Snake and, taking pity, placed it inside his coat. The Snake soon revived, but with its old wicked nature, it struck and stung its benefactor. As the Farmer lay dying, he whispered, “I pity the fool who shows kindness to the wicked.”
lesson: Kindness to the ungrateful often brings ruin.

title: The Wolf in Sheep’s Clothing
narration: One day, a Wolf found a Sheep’s skin and pulled it over himself. Thus disguised, he crept into the flock and waited for nightfall. When the Shepherd came to the fold, he picked out what he thought was the fattest Sheep and killed it for supper. But alas—it was the Wolf himself.
lesson: Evil often brings its own punishment.

title: The Dog and His Reflection
narration: A Dog once stole a piece of meat and carried it across a bridge. Looking down into the water, he saw his own reflection. “Another dog with a bigger piece!” he thought greedily. He snapped at the phantom in the water, but the meat fell from his jaws and was lost forever.
lesson: Beware lest you lose the substance by grasping at the shadow.

title: The Crow and the Sheep
narration: A Crow perched on the back of a Sheep and pecked and worried him. The Sheep said nothing. At last, the Crow settled on a Dog instead, and the Dog snapped at him fiercely. “Why do you treat the Dog so differently?” asked another Crow. “Because,” said the first Crow, “I love to bother the meek, but I fear the strong.”
lesson: The bully shows his nature by picking only on the weak.

title: The Farmer and the Lion
narration: A Farmer once prayed for protection for his fields. A Lion appeared, promising to guard them from thieves. But soon the Lion’s roar scared away the oxen, and his paws trampled the crops. The Farmer cried, “Better the thieves than the guardian!”
lesson: Some helpers do more harm than enemies.

title: The Ant and the Dove
narration: One hot day, an Ant came to drink at a brook, but it slipped and fell into the water. A Dove saw its struggle and dropped a leaf close by. The Ant climbed on and was saved. Soon after, a hunter aimed his bow at the Dove. The Ant ran quickly and bit the hunter’s foot. He missed his shot, and the Dove flew free.
lesson: A kindness is never wasted.

title: The Boys and the Frogs
narration: Some boys were playing at the edge of a pond, throwing stones into the water for fun. The stones struck the Frogs and hurt them terribly. “Boys!” cried the Frogs, “What is sport to you is death to us.”
lesson: What is fun to one may be death to another.

title: The Lion and the Three Bulls
narration: Three Bulls grazed together in peace. A Lion wanted to eat them but could not face them united. So he whispered lies until the Bulls quarreled and grazed apart. Then, one by one, the Lion killed them all.
lesson: United we stand, divided we fall.

title: The Monkey and the Fishermen
narration: A Monkey sat watching some Fishermen casting their nets. Curious, he came down and tried to do as they did. But the net entangled him, and he nearly drowned. “Alas,” he cried, “I should have kept to monkey business instead of meddling in things I did not understand.”
lesson: Don’t meddle in what you don’t understand.

title: The Old Woman and the Doctor
narration: Once upon a time, an Old Woman hired a Doctor to cure her failing eyesight. “If I recover, you shall have a fine reward,” she promised. But the cunning Doctor, while treating her, secretly carried away her furniture piece by piece. When she recovered her sight, she found her house bare. The Doctor demanded payment, but she cried, “You have cured my blindness, for I now clearly see I’ve been robbed by a thief!”
lesson: Beware of those who pretend to help but seek only gain.

title: The Ass in the Lion’s Skin
narration: A foolish Ass once found a Lion’s skin and put it on. Proud of his disguise, he wandered through the forest, frightening all the animals. But when he brayed loudly, the Fox laughed and said, “If you had held your tongue, you might have frightened me too. But your voice betrays you.”
lesson: Clothes may disguise a fool, but words will always betray him.

title: The Miser and His Gold
narration: There once was a Miser who buried his gold deep in the ground. Each day he came to dig it up and gaze at it lovingly. A thief discovered the hiding place and stole it all. The Miser, in despair, cried out. A neighbor said, “Pray, did you ever use the gold?” “No,” said the Miser, “I only looked at it.” “Then look at the hole,” replied the neighbor, “for it is just as useful as your treasure.”
lesson: Wealth unused is as useless as no wealth at all.

title: The Oxen and the Axle-Trees
narration: A pair of Oxen were drawing a heavy wagon along a muddy road. The Axle-Trees creaked terribly with every turn of the wheels. The Oxen said, “What have you to complain of? We bear all the load, while you who creak loudly do nothing but make noise.”
lesson: Those who complain the most often suffer the least.

title: The Eagle and the Arrow
narration: An Eagle, soaring high, was shot by an Archer. As he looked at the arrow piercing his wing, he saw it was feathered with his own plumes. “Alas,” he sighed, “I perish by weapons furnished from my own body.”
lesson: Our own gifts may sometimes turn against us.

title: The Horse and the Stag
narration: A Horse had a meadow all to himself until a Stag came and fed there too. Angry, the Horse asked a Man for help. “I will help you,” said the Man, “if you let me bridle you and ride you.” The Horse agreed. Together they chased the Stag away. But the Horse soon found he had lost his freedom and was a servant forever.
lesson: Seeking revenge may cost more than it’s worth.

title: The Wolf and the Crane
narration: A greedy Wolf once swallowed a bone that stuck in his throat. In agony, he begged a Crane to put her long beak inside and pull it out. The Crane risked her neck and did so. When she asked for her reward, the Wolf snarled, “Be content that you put your head in a wolf’s mouth and still live to tell the tale!”
lesson: Ungrateful people will never reward kindness.

title: The Shepherd Boy and the Wolf
narration: A Shepherd Boy, tending sheep, thought it amusing to cry out: “Wolf! Wolf!” The villagers rushed to his aid, only to find there was no wolf. He tricked them several times. But one day, a Wolf truly came. The boy cried louder than ever, but no one believed him. The Wolf fell upon the flock, and many sheep were lost.
lesson: Liars are not believed, even when they speak the truth.

title: The Fox Without a Tail
narration: A Fox once lost his tail in a trap. Ashamed, he tried to persuade the other Foxes to cut off theirs too. “A tail is useless and heavy,” he argued. But one clever Fox replied, “If you had not lost your tail, you would not talk so.”
lesson: Don’t trust advice from someone who speaks only for his own interest.

title: The Goat and the Goatherd
narration: A Goatherd drove his flock into a cave during a storm. Inside, he found some wild Goats and shut them in with his own. He fed the wild Goats better, hoping they would stay. When the storm ended, they ran away, saying, “If you betray your own goats for us, how can we trust you?”
lesson: Faithless to friends, faithless to all.

title: The Farmer and the Stork
narration: A Farmer set nets to catch cranes that were destroying his crops. Among them he found a Stork. The Stork pleaded, “Spare me! I am not like these cranes. I am a good bird, I honor my parents.” But the Farmer said, “I caught you with the thieves, and you must die with them.”
lesson: You are judged by the company you keep.

title: The Dog in the Manger
narration: A Dog lay in a manger filled with hay. When the oxen came in hungry, he growled and would not let them eat. “You neither eat hay yourself nor let others enjoy it,” they said.
lesson: Envy prevents others from enjoying what we cannot use ourselves.

title: The Fisherman and the Little Fish
narration: A Fisherman had caught a tiny Fish. The Fish begged, “Spare me now, I am too small. If you let me grow, I’ll be worth more later.” But the Fisherman replied, “Better a little sure thing today than a great hope tomorrow.”
lesson: A small gain certain is better than a great gain uncertain.

title: The Lion in Love
narration: A Lion fell in love with a maiden. He asked her father for her hand. The father, terrified, agreed only on one condition: that the Lion cut out his teeth and claws. The Lion did so out of love, but then the father mocked him: “Without teeth or claws, how can you protect her—or yourself?”
lesson: Love without wisdom may destroy a person’s strength.

title: The Cat and the Birds
narration: A Cat heard that the Birds in a cage were sick. He dressed as a doctor and came to them. “I have medicine,” he said sweetly. But one of the Birds chirped: “Stay where you are, doctor! We see your claws too clearly.”
lesson: Beware of enemies who pretend to be friends.

title: The Man and the Satyr
narration: A Man once made friends with a Satyr. On a cold morning, the Man blew on his hands. “Why?” asked the Satyr. “To warm them,” said the Man. Later, at supper, the Man blew on his hot soup. “Why?” asked the Satyr again. “To cool it,” the Man answered. “Then,” cried the Satyr, “I will have nothing to do with one who can blow hot and cold with the same breath!”
lesson: Avoid those who are inconsistent and cannot be trusted.

title: The Mischievous Dog
narration: A Dog had the habit of biting. His master hung a bell around his neck to warn others. The Dog grew proud of the bell and thought it was a mark of honor. But an old dog said, “That bell is not for fame but for shame—to mark you as dangerous.”
lesson: What seems like glory may in fact be disgrace.

title: The North Wind and the Sun
narration: The North Wind and the Sun once disputed who was stronger. They agreed to test their power on a traveler’s cloak. The Wind blew with all his force, but the more he blew, the tighter the man wrapped his cloak. Then the Sun shone warmly, and soon the traveler removed it. The Sun was declared the stronger.
lesson: Gentleness and warmth achieve more than force and fury.

title: The Crow and the Pitcher
narration: In a dry summer, a thirsty Crow found a pitcher with a little water at the bottom. He could not reach it with his beak. Then he dropped pebbles one by one into the pitcher, until the water rose high enough for him to drink.
lesson: Necessity is the mother of invention.

title: The Fox and the Monkey
narration: Once the Beasts chose the Monkey as their king, charmed by his dancing and tricks. The Fox, jealous, led the Monkey to a trap with food inside. The Monkey rushed in and was caught. “You see what a king we have,” said the Fox.
lesson: A ruler must have wisdom, not just charm.

title: The Horse and the Groom
narration: A Groom once fed his master’s Horse only enough to keep him alive, saving the best food for himself. When war came, the master mounted the Horse, but it was too weak and stumbled. The master said bitterly: “You have betrayed me when I needed you most.”
lesson: Neglect weakens even the strongest ally.

title: The Bull and the Calf
narration: A Calf mockingly told a Bull: “Father, you are so big, yet you let men tie you up and beat you.” The Bull replied: “I endure it because they bring me food. Wait until you grow—then you will understand that service sometimes comes with burdens.”
lesson: Strength must often yield to necessity.

title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
narration: A Sailor once carried a Monkey aboard ship. When the ship wrecked, both were cast into the sea. A Dolphin swam up, thinking the Monkey was a man, and carried him ashore. “Are you from Athens?” asked the Dolphin. “Yes, of course,” lied the Monkey. “I even know the king!” The Dolphin replied, “The king of Athens has no court.” Realizing the Monkey was a liar, the Dolphin dropped him into the sea.
lesson: Liars are soon exposed and punished.

title: The Eagle and the Arrow
narration: An Eagle was shot by an arrow. As he looked at it, he recognized the feathers as his own. “Alas,” he said, “I am destroyed by weapons made from my own body.”
lesson: We are often hurt most by the things we ourselves provide.

title: The Dog and His Reflection
narration: A Dog was crossing a stream with a piece of meat in his mouth. Seeing his reflection in the water, he thought it was another dog with a bigger piece. He snapped at the reflection, dropping his own meat into the stream.
lesson: Greed loses all.

title: The Frogs Asking for a King
narration: The Frogs begged Jupiter for a king. He threw them a log, which fell with a splash. At first they feared it, but soon they climbed and mocked it. They prayed for another king. Jupiter sent a stork, who ate them one by one.
lesson: Better no ruler than a cruel one.

title: The Wolf in Sheep’s Clothing
narration: A Wolf found a sheep’s fleece and wrapped himself in it to sneak among the flock. At night he was caught and killed by the shepherd, who mistook him for a sheep thief.
lesson: Evil disguises itself but is eventually found out.

title: The Old Woman and the Doctor
narration: An Old Woman invited a Doctor to cure her failing eyesight, promising to pay if he succeeded. Each time he came, the Doctor stole some furniture. When her sight improved, she refused to pay. “You’ve stolen my house,” she said. The Doctor was taken to court and punished.
lesson: Cheaters are often caught by their own greed.

title: The Peacock and Juno
narration: The Peacock complained to Juno, “Why have you given me beauty but not the voice of a nightingale?” Juno replied: “You have beauty, strength, and splendor. Do not seek what is not yours, lest you lose what you have.”
lesson: Be content with your own gifts.

title: The Farmer and His Sons
narration: A dying Farmer called his sons and said: “There is treasure hidden in the vineyard. Dig for it.” When he died, the sons dug, but found no gold. Instead, the soil, well turned, bore a richer harvest than ever.
lesson: Hard work is the true treasure.
